page_content='18 | P a g e  

 
 
\x0cTwo unexpected brick pipes were identified to the south of Oakover Road during the course of the 
LXRP works. Following consultation with Heritage Victoria these features were added to extent of VHI 
site H7822-2387 and excavated under the existing consent C1600. When the spatial data was collated 
following the excavations it became apparent the brick pipe [208] was actually located slightly to the 
south of the portion of the VHI site extent added to investigate it. The VHI extent of site H7822-2387 
has been updated to reflect the actual location of the brick pipe [208] and the areas that were fully 
excavated to the natural deposit at the completion of all works. The proposed revised site extent is 
presented in Map 4 in Section 7.1.  

The excavation dates and archaeologists involved in the excavations are presented in Table 2. 

Table 2: Excavation dates and archaeologists under C1600 

Activity 

Dates 

Lead Archaeologist 

Field Archaeologists' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5211_H7822-2387 Bell Railway Station Archaeological Precinct.pdf'}

page_content='1 | P a g e  

 
 
\x0c1.2 Location of the Site 

The VHI site ‘Bell Railway Station Archaeological Precinct’ (H7822-2387) comprises four discrete areas 
within the eastern and western rail reserve and rail corridor between Bell Street and Miller Street, in 
the  suburb  of  Preston,  Melbourne  (Map  1).  The  three  southern  areas  of  the  Bell  Railway  Station 
Archaeological Precinct form the study area for the purposes of this report (Map 2). The study area, 
the former Oakover Road gatehouse is contained to the eastern rail reserve and corridor, adjacent to 
the Melbourne and Mernda railway. The site is located on the northeast side of the Oakover Road 
railway crossing between the railway line and Railway Place East, south of Bell Station.  

The relevant cadastral information for VHI site H7822-2387 is provided in Table 1 below. 

Table 1: Current cadastral information for VHI site H7822-2387' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5211_H7822-2387 Bell Railway Station Archaeological Precinct.pdf'}

page_content='3.2 Aims 

As per the conditions of Consent C1600 the archaeological excavation program aimed to determine 
the  integrity,  extent  and  cultural  heritage  significance  of  any  identified  historical  archaeological 
remains of infrastructure associated with the late-19th century Whittlesea Railway Line, including the 
former Oakover Road gatehouse, prior to the LXRP works. 

3.3 Methodology  

Following the methodology outlined in the Former Oakover Road Gatehouse H7822-2387, HV Consent 
Application  (Vincent  Clarke  and  Associates,  2020)  and  Conditions  5-7  of  Heritage  Victoria  issued 
Consent C1600 (Appendix 1), two targeted test trenches were initially excavated to determine the 
archaeological potential of the site. These test trenches were subsequently expanded to explore the 
extent of identified archaeology. The excavation of several construction trenches was monitored in 
between the excavation of the test trenches and the subsequent wider excavations.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5211_H7822-2387 Bell Railway Station Archaeological Precinct.pdf'}

1.paragraph: The excavation site was located at the corner of Swanston and Franklin streets in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.
source:
page_content='Artefact Analysis 

A total of 533 artefacts, by number of individual fragments were recovered during the excavation program. The 
minimum number of vessels (MNV) count was 131. Sixty-six percent of the site assemblage was recovered from 
context (105) which was described as an artefact rich fill of a rectangular pit to the west of the mapped cesspit 
location.  The  artefact  assemblage  was  found  to  date  within  the  late  19th  to  20th  centuries  and  is  therefore 
considered to be of low significance. Heritage Victoria (HV) has approved the discard of the entire assemblage, 
which will be undertaken following the submission of this report. 

Aboriginal Cultural Heritage  

No Aboriginal Cultural Heritage was identified during the archaeological program. 

Significance' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5211_H7822-2387 Bell Railway Station Archaeological Precinct.pdf'}

page_content='The Act provides blanket protection for all historical archaeological places in Victoria that are 75 years 
old or more. The VHI is a statutory listing of all known historical archaeological sites in Victoria, except 
for Commonwealth owned/managed places, which do not fall within Heritage Victoria jurisdiction. 
The VHI includes sites whose archaeological significance ranges from low to high, including places with 
archaeological potential.   

Under Section 123 of the Act it is an offence to knowingly or negligently deface, damage or otherwise 
interfere with, or carry out an act, likely to endanger a site recorded in the Heritage Inventory; or an 
archaeological site which is not recorded in the Heritage Inventory, without obtaining the appropriate 
consent from the Executive Director of the Heritage Victoria.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5211_H7822-2387 Bell Railway Station Archaeological Precinct.pdf'}

page_content='This summation was partially borne out with several in situ posts and two in situ brick pipes uncovered 
that  are  believed  to  date  to  the  late  19th  to  early  20th  century  occupation  of  the  site.  A  small 
assemblage  of  artefacts  was  examined  but  were  found  to  be  of  low  significance.  Due  to  these 
circumstances, the contributions of the site to the historical record are limited.  

6.2.1 Historical Themes 

The following thematic framework is taken from Victoria’s Framework of Historical Themes document 
issued by Heritage Victoria and a discussion of which is part of the historical archaeological assessment 
of the VHI site. The themes are intended to assist in identifying, assessing, interpreting and managing 
heritage places and objects. It encourages a comprehensive approach to heritage identification and 
protection, and provides a comparative context for deeper understanding of the significance of places 
and objects.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5211_H7822-2387 Bell Railway Station Archaeological Precinct.pdf'}

2.paragraph: The VHI site H7822-2387 is located in the city of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. It consists of four distinct areas within the eastern and western rail reserves and corridors along Bell Street and Miller Street in the suburb of Preston.

old or more. The VHI is a statutory listing of all known historical archaeological sites in Victoria, except 
for Commonwealth owned/managed places, which do not fall within Heritage Victoria jurisdiction. 
The VHI includes sites whose archaeological significance ranges from low to high, including places with 
archaeological potential.   

Under Section 123 of the Act it is an offence to knowingly or negligently deface, damage or otherwise 
interfere with, or carry out an act, likely to endanger a site recorded in the Heritage Inventory; or an 
archaeological site which is not recorded in the Heritage Inventory, without obtaining the appropriate

The VHI site ‘Bell Railway Station Archaeological Precinct’ (H7822-2387) comprises four discrete areas 
within the eastern and western rail reserve and rail corridor between Bell Street and Miller Street, in 
the  suburb  of  Preston,  Melbourne  (Map  1).  The  three  southern  areas  of  the  Bell  Railway  Station 
Archaeological Precinct form the study area for the purposes of this report (Map 2). The study area, 
the former Oakover Road gatehouse is contained to the eastern rail reserve and corridor, adjacent to 
the Melbourne and Mernda railway. The site is located on the northeast side of the Oakover Road 
railway crossing between the railway line and Railway Place East, south of Bell Station.  

The relevant cadastral information for VHI site H7822-2387 is provided in Table 1 below.

page_content='ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS 

Andrew Long + Associates 

Lauren Mitchell – Project Manager 

Rebekka Hocking – Project Manager 

Haley Geiberras – Project Archaeologist 

Helen Nguyen-Mallen – GIS Officer 

Belle Leslie – Assistant Archaeologist 

Heritage Victoria 

Paul Pepdjonovic – Senior Project Archaeologist (Major Projects) 

Jacinta Bauer - Archaeologist 

LXRP 

NWPA 

Sarah Mclaughlin 

Tham Gunasekara 

 
 
 
 
\x0cEXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

Introduction 

This  report  presents  the  findings  of  recent  archaeological  investigations  conducted  under  Heritage  Victoria 
issued Consent C1600, by Andrew Long and Associates (ALA) on behalf of the Level Crossing Removal Project 
(LXRP). Ground disturbing works were required within the Victorian Heritage Inventory (VHI) site: Bell Railway 
Station  Archaeological  Precinct  (formerly  Former  Oakover  Road  Gatehouse)  to  facilitate  the  removal  of  the 
Oakover Road level crossing. 

Historical Background' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5211_H7822-2387 Bell Railway Station Archaeological Precinct.pdf'}

page_content='As  stated  in  the  Letter  of Findings  (Hocking  2021)  the  site  remains  significant  at  a  local  level  as  it 
represents mid-19th to early 20th century rail infrastructure. The site is of archaeological significance 
as  the  identified  remains  provide  a  material  record  of  the  original  Gatehouse  structure  as  part  of 
Victoria’s early rail industry and its demolition phases. The archaeological investigations conducted 
under C1600 did not identify any sub-floor or cesspit deposits to further add to the interpretation of 
the site. The overall site is  assessed with a low-moderate level of historical significance based on its 
association with the Victorian rail industry and the early development of Preston.  

6.3.1 Assemblage Statement of Significance' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5211_H7822-2387 Bell Railway Station Archaeological Precinct.pdf'}

As per the conditions of Consent C1600 the archaeological excavation program aimed to determine 
the  integrity,  extent  and  cultural  heritage  significance  of  any  identified  historical  archaeological 
remains of infrastructure associated with the late-19th century Whittlesea Railway Line, including the 
former Oakover Road gatehouse, prior to the LXRP works. 

3.3 Methodology  

Following the methodology outlined in the Former Oakover Road Gatehouse H7822-2387, HV Consent 
Application  (Vincent  Clarke  and  Associates,  2020)  and  Conditions  5-7  of  Heritage  Victoria  issued 
Consent C1600 (Appendix 1), two targeted test trenches were initially excavated to determine the 
archaeological potential of the site. These test trenches were subsequently expanded to explore the
